III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff Qualifications; volunteer, contractors
Section on central registry.
Description (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster care worker engaged in inappropriate interactions with
foster child and relative caregiver, including verbal harassment
and putting their hand in child's shirt.
Investigation Complainant reported concerns to DCWL on 1/12/24,
summarized as follows:
• Foster Care Worker allowed child’s mom to follow Relative
Caregiver to the car after a visit. Mom put her hand down
the child’s shirt and tried to take a picture.
• Foster Care Worker went to Relative Caregiver’s home on
another date and also put her hands down the child’s shirt.
• The agency is harassing the child and Relative Caregiver.
Relative Caregiver was contacted via email on 1/12/24.
Relative Caregiver(RC) reported after a parenting time visit at the
agency the child’s mother followed them out to the car. RC stated
there is a court order that the mother is not supposed to do that.
While at the car, the mother looked in the child’s shirt. The child is
5 years old. RC was asked if the mother was looking at a bruise or
mark, or something the child asked her to look at. RC stated there
was no reason to look in the child’s shirt. RC stated that after the
visit, Foster Care Worker (FCW) called RC back to the agency to
give the child a birthday gift. While there, FCW put her hand down
the child’s shirt. FCW did not indicate why she did this. However,
FCW stated she did not see anything except possibly a rash. At a
later date, during a visit at RC’s house, FCW was asked why she
looked down the child’s shirt. FCW denied this occurred and
called the child a liar. RC was asked if they could clarify how they
felt the agency was “harassing” them. RC clarified that the child’s
mother harasses them by making statements about returning
home, which scares the child. RC reported informing FCW,
Supervisor, Agency Director, and a lawyer of these concerns. The
agency put steps in place regarding contact between RC and the
mother. RC did not report any ways they felt the agency harassed
them.
2

Agency Director was interviewed via TEAMS on 1/25/24.
Agency Director reported she had several phone calls with RC.
RC and the child’s mother have a difficult relationship and RC
complains frequently about things that he disagrees with in the
case. Agency Director reported they attempt to discuss these
concerns and problem solve with RC. However, RC has not been
very receptive. Agency Director stated they continue to service the
case with the children’s best interest in mind and address RC’s
concerns as they are able. Agency Director denied any prior
complaints from RC about the mother or worker putting her hand
down the child’s shirt.
Program Manager was interviewed via TEAMS on 1/25/24.
Program Manager reported they were aware of RC’s frustration
with the case. A Family Team Meeting (FTM) was held on 1/17/24
to discuss and develop solutions. RC attended the meeting and
stated the things he was dissatisfied with. However, he did not
seem willing to talk about ways to resolve the concerns.
Program Manager reported RC and the child’s mother have had a
challenging relationship, which seems to be where much of his
frustration stems from. Program Manager also reported that there
have been challenges with RC as a placement. For the first half of
the 2023-2024 school year the child had 29 school absences and
several tardies, the child is not attending therapy as required, and
RC has been late to parenting time in addition to interacting
negatively with the mother in front of the children. These issues
were discussed with RC at the FTM. Program Manager believed
this information was relevant to the investigation as there seems
to be a pattern of RC making allegations about the agency, when
he is held accountable by the agency about following the child’s
treatment plan. Regarding anyone looking in or putting their hand
in the child’s shirt, Program Manager did not have any first-hand
knowledge of any situation where this occurred. However, she did
recall Children’s Services being called due to some marks on the
child’s chest several months ago. Program Manager denied any
prior complaints from RC about the mother or worker putting her
hand down the child’s shirt. Program Manager stated she was not
aware of any court order to prevent the child’s mom from speaking
with relative or approaching them outside of the agency.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via phone on 1/29/24.
FCW stated there are no court orders in place to prevent the
child’s mother from walking out to the car or interacting with RC.
However, due to RC being negative towards the mother in front of
the children, someone from the agency walks the children out to
RC’s car, while the mother waits inside the agency. This plan has
3

been in place for several months. FCW has not observed the
child’s mother following RC out to the car recently. There was one
time in October 2023 that the diaper bag was left in the visit room
and the mother ran it out to RC’s car. FCW did not observe any
problems between RC and the mother at that time. Regarding
FCW or the mother looking down the child’s shirt, FCW recalled
that in July 2023 the child reported some scratches on her chest
during parenting time. The scratches were at the neckline of the
child’s shirt. The mother was able to view the scratches without
moving the child’s shirt. RC was not present when this occurred
during parenting time. The mother asked FCW to look at the
scratches. When the visit ended FCW walked the child out to RC’s
car. Child got in the car and FCW was able to view the marks at
the child’s neckline. FCW denied ever looking down the child’s
shirt or putting her hand down the child’s shirt. FCW described the
marks to appear to be skin irritation, not scratches. An
investigation later determined the irritation was due to the child
falling off of her scooter a few days prior to the visit. A safety plan
was developed regarding supervision of the child at RC’s home.
The safety plan was reviewed at RC’s home a few days later.
During that home visit, RC began making negative, untrue
statements about the child’s mother. FCW discussed with RC that
the child may be sharing some inaccurate information, which is
causing tension between RC and the mother. FCW denied ever
calling the child a liar but did state the child seemed to be
manipulating the situation and triangulating with her mother and
RC. Regarding RC stating that his concerns have not been
addressed, FCW said this is untrue. There have been several
phone calls, emails, and meetings to discuss his concerns. FCW
reported RC’s concerns seem to increase whenever the agency
discusses RC not following the treatment plan. FCW relayed the
same placement concerns as Program Manager and indicated the
agency continues to address this.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via phone on 1/29/24.
Supervisor reported she was not aware of any court orders
indicating the child’s mother could not go out to the car or interact
with RC. Supervisor stated she was not present for or heard of an
allegation about any incident where the child’s mother or FCW
looked in or put their hand in the child’s shirt. Supervisor recalled
hearing about the child having some scratches on her chest and
children’s services being contacted. Supervisor stated RC
previously mentioned FCW looked at the marks on the child, but
never indicated FCW looked down her shirt or acted
inappropriately. During a recent FTM RC brought up the issue of
FCW calling the child a liar. This was the first time Supervisor
4

heard this allegation. Supervisor had never witnessed FCW call
the child a liar. Supervisor stated that she had many
conversations with RC. When he is dissatisfied with Supervisors
responses, RC has a habit of bypassing the Program Manager
and speaking directly with the Agency Director. RC repeatedly
reports the same information about being upset with the mother
and feeling the agency should not work toward reunification.
Supervisor reported explaining how the foster care system works,
several times. RC’s complaints seem to be more frequent when
the agency addresses concerns about the child’s placement with
RC. When the agency attempts to discuss what needs to be done
to follow the service plan, RC deflects and makes complaints
about the child’s mother. Supervisor reported there have been
three FTMs to discuss the concerns about school absences and
therapy attendance. As these issues have not improved,
alternative placements may need to be considered.
Documents reviewed
MiSACWIS file review:
• A review of FTMs determined there was no documentation
that RC reported a concern about the mother or FCW
looking down or putting their hand down the child’s shirt.
• A review of court orders determined there are no court
orders preventing the mother from interacting with RC or
walking her children out of parenting time to RC’s car.
• A review of case contacts determined there were no
documented reports from RC about the mother or FCW
putting their hand down the child’s shirt.
• A case contact from 7/26/23 reported that during parenting
time the child asked her mother to look at her chest. Some
red scratches were observed. After the visit FCW walked
child to RC’s car and looked at the scratches. An incident
report was completed and children’s services was
contacted.
• Children’s Services allegation intake dated 7/26/23
indicated that during parenting time the child was observed
with red scratches on her chest. The allegation was
transferred to the agency for review. As RC is not a
licensed foster parent, a special evaluation was not
completed. But additional contacts were entered. RC
reported to the agency that the marks were from the child
falling off her scooter. A safety plan was developed and
discussed with RC. RC did not report any concerns at that
time about the mother or FCW looking at the child’s chest.
5

Analysis Based on the information obtained through interviews and
document review, no information was found to confirm this
allegation.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12210 Grievance handling
Section (1) An agency shall have a written grievance handling
Description procedure as mandated by section 8a of the foster care
and adoption services act, 1994 PA 203, MCL
722.958a, and known as the 'foster parent's bill of rights
law.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency did not respond to a grievance filed by the relative
caregiver.
Investigation Relative Caregiver was contacted via email on 1/12/24.
Relative Caregiver was asked for clarification regarding the
allegation. On 1/14/24 Relative Caregiver clarified they did not file
a grievance with the agency.
Agency Director was interviewed via TEAMS on 1/25/24.
Agency Director confirmed a grievance was not filed by Relative
Caregiver. Agency Director agreed to provide RC with information
about how to file a grievance if he wished to do so.
Analysis As a grievance was not filed, no violation was found.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
